Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: First I need to identify which cases have significantly longer total resolution times The total resolution time is from the first event Receive Ticket to the last event Close Ticket for each case

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Let me calculate the duration for each case based on the timestamps provided All timestamps are in the same format so I can compute the time differences

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Starting with Case 101 Duration 2 25 hours Case 102 25 1667 hours Case 103 1 3333 hours Case 104 24 1667 hours Case 105 49 0833 hours

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Now list the durations Case 101 2 25 hours Case 102 25 1667 hours Case 103 1 3333 hours Case 104 24 1667 hours Case 105 49 0833 hours

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: To find which are significantly longer I need an average or some benchmark First calculate the average resolution time Sum of durations 102 hours Number of cases 5 Average 102 5 20 4 hours

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Now cases longer than average Case 102 25 1667 > 20 4 Case 104 24 1667 > 20 4 Case 105 49 0833 > 20 4 Cases shorter 101 and 103 are below Significantly longer Case 105 is much higher at 49 hours while 102 and 104 are around 25 and 24 hours

Name: Heuristic Reasoning - PE
Text: Perhaps define significantly longer as say more than 1 standard deviation above mean but for simplicity based on the data 101 and 103 are quick under 2 5 hours while others are longer

Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: Cases with escalations or longer waits From the log Case 102 has Escalate to Level 2 Agent Case 105 has Escalate to Level 2 Agent Case 101 103 104 do not have escalation mentioned

Name: Abductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Case 104 does not have escalation but still long duration Check the activities

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Case 104 So long wait between assign and investigate from assign at 09 30 to investigate at 13 00 thats 3 5 hours Then resolution next day Case 102 Escalate 11 30 2 5 hours after assign Investigate 14 00 2 5 hours after escalate Case 105 Escalate 10 00 50 min after investigate Investigate Issue 2024 03 02 14 00 after escalation After escalate on 03 01 10 00 next event is investigate on 03 02 14 00 which is over a day later Thats a big gap

Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: So long waiting time after escalation Now for Case 104 no escalation but long waits Identify long cases 102 104 105

Name: Hypothesis Generation - PE
Text: Root causes Presence of escalations Case 102 and 105 have escalations and are long Long waiting times between activities For Case 102 perhaps the Level 2 agent is busy or slow For Case 104 Huge gap there In Case 105 after escalate 28 hours later Thats a massive delay

Name: Inductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Potential factors 1 Escalations 2 Long waiting times between assignment and investigation 3 Delays in starting investigation after escalation Perhaps workload or agent availability

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Now to answer the task 1 Identify long cases Case 102 25 17 hours Case 104 24 17 hours Case 105 49 08 hours are longer compared to Case 101 2 25 hours and Case 103 1 33 hours

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: 2 Root causes Escalations Cases 102 and 105 have escalations and longer times In Case 105 extremely long wait after escalation 28 hours In Case 104 no escalation but long wait between activities This could be due to agent backlog or inefficiency

Name: Abductive Reasoning - PE
Text: 3 Explain and propose recommendations Escalations lead to increased cycle times Long waiting times indicate bottlenecks Recommendations Analyze the escalation process Improve agent workload management ensure prompt handoff and perhaps set SLAs Automate parts Train level 1 agents
